name: PW-adapted complementary builds specializing in offense and defense (WM-killer & DD-tank duo team)
author: ADW

posts.author: ADW
posts.content:
This is a follow-up to Cornflower's build requests here and here. In those threads, Cornflower wrote:

End-game bosses have somewhere around 85AC and 100AB, as well as occasionally stuff like OnHit Harm, OnHit Dispel and are usually plentiful. Usually they are also equipped with lots of Damage Reductions, so they take all day to kill. The only way to clear up end-game areas is a team of one WM-killer and one DD-tank.
It's not enough to just hit on 20, because the bosses will regenerate faster than you hit them. The obvious solution is to have one WM-hitter and one DD-tank working together...
I recently started playing on the same PW, and I'm interested in these specialist builds (especially the DD-tank). In other words, this is a request for: (1) a Dwarven Defender build that specializes in defense, designed specifically to work in a party with at least one offensive character in order to defeat the endgame bosses on this PW, and (2) a Weapon Master build that specializes in offense, designed to work in the DD character in the same party. Cornflower has provided further details about this particular PW in the threads linked above (and is much more familiar with the PW than I am, since I'm new there).

I'm also curious about how the characters in this party would work together in practice. For example, how does the DD-tank ensure that the boss is always hitting him instead of one-shotting the glass-cannon WM-killer? (In other games, this would be a question about how the "threat" or "aggro" mechanic works.)

posts.author: Thorsson
posts.content:
Looking at the AA, I have a couple of questions:

1. Why Knockdown? Seems a pointless Feat on an AA with 14 Str.
2. Why not get 29 AA levels for the maximum bonus (or even 30 as you get a Bonus Feat)?
3. Although you lose the extra Dex and full Elf abilities, Half-Elf allows you to take Bard, which gives you full Tumble and UMD, as well as Bard Song (which gets you back the AB you lost on Dex, plus some damage).

I guess I'm thinking of something along the lines of F8/Bd3/AA29 or Bd4/F6/AA30.

TBH is the Rapier stuff worth having? I mean he's not going to hurt a fly with one. Certainly not a boss with DR.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Well, your tank is going to get hit whatever. It's a question of scaling. Andariel will get hit less, but it will hurt more. A decent DwD will probably get hit more often, but can shrug more of it off. In the meantime, while the boss is wailing away on a stubborn dwarf, you've got a highly effective elven archer knocking chunks out of them. If both tank and killer are doing their job (remembering that the tank's main focus is to distract and occupy the attention of the enemy) then all is well. Haste is potentially useful, so long as you don't give the boss a clear run at your sniper while you're legging it. Alternatively, Defensive Stance and toe-to-toe might work. A DwD with a massive pool of HPs and EDRIII might just shrug and growl, "And?"

posts.author: ADW

Stagmeister wrote: (remembering that the tank's main focus is to distract and occupy the attention of the enemy)
How does this work mechanically in NWN? Is there some way for the DwD to ensure that the boss keeps hitting him instead of turning to one-shot a fragile WM stabbing from behind (supposing it's not just the distant AA in the party)?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: As with many things, timing is important. (Have a look through Max's Game Guide to Playing Better for more details.) If you time your flurries right, as soon as he looks over his shoulder for where that stabbing pain's coming from he gets a smack on the kneecap and turns back, he gives the fragile one time to set up another attack. Rinse and repeat. Much easier with a ranged ally, obviously, who will have scope to give a cheery wave as s/he peppers the bad dude.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Cornflower wrote: I understand the thinking of bard, but why drop Elf? You can be an elven bard.
The favored class for an Elf is Wizard, so a Elf Fighter / Bard / AA would have an experience penalty unless Fighter and Bard are kept even. The favored class for a Half-Elf is whatever class has the most levels, just like a Human, so a Half-Elf Fighter / Bard / AA would have no experience penalty. This is a very rare case of Half-Elf being the best choice of race.
